Wang~, A. Kamoa, T. Yoneda~, T. Komatsub, T. Yashimab'* ~Advanced Catalysts Research Laboratory, Advanced Technology and Research Institute, Petroleum Energy Center, 3-2-1, Sakato, Takatsu-ku, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 213, Japan bDepartment of Chemistry, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1, Ookayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan Received 4 September 1996; received in revised form 16 January 1997; accepted 21 January 1997 Abstract The influence of key parameters in the isomerization of n-heptane over Pt-loaded H)3 catalysts was studied at temperatures lower than 250 under atmospheric pressure. The highest yield of isomerized products was obtained at 210. The conversion of n-heptane increased with contact time (W/F), while the selectivity to isomers decreased. The higher the hydrogen partial pressure, the higher the selectivity to isomers. It was found that Pt/Hj3 catalyst showed a good stability for 78 h at the reaction temperature of 220. The effect of metallic sites and acid sites (Si/A1 ratios) on the catalytic property was studied. The higher the content of Pt, the higher the selectivity to isomers, and the lower the acidity of zeolite/3, the higher the selectivity to isomers at the same conversion. Keywords: Heptane isomerization; Zeolite/3; Platinum/zeolite catalyst I. Introduction Although zeolite/3 was first synthesized in 1967 [1], studies on this acid catalyst for potential applications in petroleum chemistry, refining, and fine chemical production began only recently [2-6]. This is due, in part, to the late description of its framework structure [7-11 ]. Zeolite/3 has a three-dimensional, interconnected channel system with I2-membered elliptical openings having mean diameters of 0.64.76 nm. It is ordered as a large-pore zeolite between faujasite and morde- * Corresponding author. 1Present address. Zeolite fl is reportedly a good catalyst for several important reactions: for example, cracking [12], hydrotreating [ 13], benzene alkylation with light olefins [14], isobutane alkylation with n-butene [15], and isopropylation of cumene to diisopropylbenzenes [16]. Environmental Protection Agency regulations for phasing out lead additives from gasoline had a significant impact on the refinery industry. As a result, there has been a sharp rise in the requirements for octane enhancement processes. The isomerization of light straight paraffins is the most effective among the available octane enhancement processes. Therefore, the isomerization of straight chain paraffins into branched chain paraffins will become increasingly important. The traditional isomerization catalyst is Pt-loaded chlorided alumina, which is very active and can be operated at low temperatures, but will cause corrosion and pollution problems. The use of zeolites as a support can eliminate such problems. The noble-metal-loaded zeolite catalysts display high catalytic activity for the isomerization of alkanes in processes with the purpose of enhancing the octane number of automotive fuels. In typical bifunctional catalyst formulations, the noble metal catalyzes hydrogenation-dehydrogenation reactions, and the zeolite acid sites catalyze the carbocation rearrangements. In contrast to mono-functional catalysis, a synergism exists between metallic sites and acid sites in bifunctional catalysts leading to an enhanced catalytic activity and higher yields of products with tertiary and quaternary carbon atoms [17]. Pt-loaded mordenite (Pt/HM) catalysts have been used commercially for the isomerization of C5-C6 normal alkanes to higher octane branched isomers [ 18]. Hydroisomerization of n-alkanes over Pt-loaded dealuminated Y zeolite (Pt/HY) has also been studied by research- ers [19,20]. However, the activities of Pt/HM and Pt/HY catalysts were very low, and a rapid deactivation occurred over Pt/HM catalyst [21]. It has been shown recently [22,23] that Pt-loaded Hfl catalysts have very high activity and selectivity in n-hexane isomerization. n-Heptane constitutes an important fraction of naphtha. However, because of its low octane number (RON=0), it is separated and diverted to the catalytic reformer where hydrocracking occurs under more severe conditions, leading to increase the yield of the undesirable light hydrocarbon products. Thus, the need to isomerize n- heptane to mono-branched isomers (RON=42--65) and preferentially to multi- branched isomers (RON---80-112) is obvious, n-Heptane was chosen as the reactant also because its cracking occurs easily, making it possible to estimate correctly the isomerization/cracking selectivity of the catalysts. Blomsma et al. [24] have reported the isomerization of n-heptane on Pd/H/3 catalysts in view of the reaction mechanism. In this study, the catalytic properties of Pt-loaded H/3 catalysts in n-heptane isomerization was studied. Effects of the acid and metallic functions of Pt/l-I/3 catalysts on the catalytic performance were mainly discussed using Pt/H/3 catalysts with various contents of platinum and different acid concentrations. ZB. Wang et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 119-132 121 2. Experimental Zeolite/3 with different aluminum contents was synthesized by a hydrothermal method according to previously reported recipes [ 1,25,26]. The atomic ratios of Si to A1 in zeolite/3 are 18, 21, 23, and 30. They are denoted as/3t, where t is Si/AI ratio. Mordenite was synthesized hydrothermally, and dealuminated by leaching with 6 N HNO3 at 100 for 8 h. Y type zeolite was obtained from Tosoh. All the parent zeolites were converted into the NH~- form by ion-exchange with ammo- nium nitrate solution. Platinum was introduced into zeolites by a conventional ion- exchange technique [27] with 2.6 mg Pt/ml Pt(NH3)4C12 aqueous solution at 98-C under stirring. All samples obtained were air dried at 110, and stored in a desiccator containing a saturated aqueous solution of NH4C1. All catalysts were pretreated with flowing oxygen diluted with helium at 130~C for 1 h, at 300 for 2 h, at 350 for 3 h and at 450 for 4 h, then reduced with flowing hydrogen at 400 for 2 h and at 450 for 1.5 h before reaction. The isomerization of n-heptane was carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor system under atmospheric pressure with a quartz reactor of 16 mm ID. The mixture of hydrogen and n-heptane with the molar ratio of 7.5 was fed into the reactor. Contact time (W/F) is 3.2 g h mo1-1. Products were analyzed on-line by a gas chromatograph (FID) equipped with a 100 m, 0.25 mm ID PetrocolTM DH fused silica capillary column. The column temperatures were increased from 3 8C to 71~C at a heating rate of 2 rain-1. The yield, the selectivity and the product distribution were expressed on a carbon number basis. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Effect of reaction conditions The results of n-heptane isomerization at 230 over various Pt-loaded zeolite catalysts are shown in Table 1. Data were collected at 1 h on stream. HM and HY are dealuminated mordenite and dealuminated Y type zeolites, respectively. Si/A1 ratios of HY, HM and H/3 are 7, 13, and 21, respectively. As a general result, the products of n-heptane reaction consist of cracking products (mainly propane and isobutane) and C7-isomers including mono-branched isomers (2-methylhexane (2- MHex), 3-MHex and 3-ethylpentane (3-EP)), and multi-branched isomers (2,2- dimethylpentane (2,2-DMP), 2,3-DMP, 2,4-DME 3,3-DME 2,2,3-trimethylbutane (2,2,3-TMB), and dimethylcyclopentane (DMCP)). Pt/H/321 catalyst showed the highest conversion of n-heptane, while Pt/HM13 catalyst showed the lowest. The lower activity of Pt/HM13 may be due to its faster deactivation. This is probably related to its uni-dimensional pore system and higher density of strong acid sites [28,29]. The lower activity may also be due to the blockage of the pore openings by platinum crystallites, which has been confirmed by the study of m-xylene 122 Z.B. In agreement with this blockage, the activity of benzene hydrogenation at 100 was definitely smaller on Pt/HM13 (0.03%) than that on Pt/HY7 (11.8%) and Pt/H/321 (15.1%). It has been reported that the acidity of H/3 is stronger than that of HY [30]. This may be the reason of the higher activity and the lower selectivity to isomers over Pt/H/321 than those over Pt/HY7. Table 1 also shows that the isomer distributions over these three catalysts were different. This will be discussed later. In order to get high yield of isomers over Pt/H/3 catalyst, effects of the reaction conditions on the performance of n-heptane isomerization have been studied. 3.2. Effect of reaction temperature The principal dependence of n-heptane transformation over Pt/H/321 catalyst on reaction temperature is illustrated in Fig. 1. The conversion of n-heptane increased with reaction temperature, while the selectivity to isomers decreased. The total yield of all C7-isomers passed through a maximum at 210, indicating the consumption of the isomerized products in consecutive cracking reactions at higher temperatures. Table 2 shows that propane and butane, in equimolar amounts, were the major cracking products, amounting to 99 mol% of the cracking products. Another feature worth noting is the high isobutane/n-butane ratio, indicating that most of the cracking reactions follow the rearrangements of the n-heptane skeleton. Namely, the cracking products of n-heptane over Pt/H/3 catalysts can be interpreted by the classic bifunctional hydrocracking. Recently, a different situation has been identified by Blomsma and co-workers [24] in the conversion of heptane over Pd/ H/3. The cracking of heptane over Pd/H/3 is interpreted as a combination of classic bifunctional hydrocracking and dimerization cracking, based on the result that C4 cracking products were formed in excess of C3 products, and that the sum of the C3 and C4 products were less than 200 mol per 100 mol of feed cracked. The difference of the metal (Pt and Pd) and Si/A1 ratios of zeolite/3 (21 and 12.5) maybe leads to the different cracking mechanisms. ZB. Another feature worth noting is an approaching 100% intercept of the selectivity to isomers. As shown in Fig. 3, the ratios ofisomerized to cracked n-heptane (I/C) decreased with increasing W/F. This result verifies that n-heptane is converted first into isomers, then successively into cracking products. This result indicates that the isomerization first leads to mono-branched isomers mainly, then to multi-branched ones. Fig. 4 shows the fraction of multi-branched isomers (IBI) in C7-isomers against n-heptane conversion over various Pt-loaded zeolite catalysts (Pt/HM13, Pt/HY7 and Pt/H/321). The conversion of n-heptane was changed by changing W/F. The fraction of multi-branched isomers over Pt/HM13 was independent of the con- version of n-heptane. The fractions of multi-branched isomers over Pt/HY7 and Pt/ H/321 increased almost linearly with the conversion, the former having a steeper slope. The fraction over Pt/HM catalyst was the highest at lower conversions, but the deactivation of Pt/HM was very fast. Therefore, the highest yield of multi- branched isomers can be obtained over Pt/HY. The formation of isobutane can be readily explained by the cracking of 2-MHex, 2,2-DMP, and 2,4-DMP, according to the carbocation-type mechanism of cleavage [31 ]. We have already reported that the heat of ammonia adsorption is 80-100 kJ mo1-1 on H/3 and 100-125 kJ mo1-1 on HM [22]. 4. Effect of Pt sites and acid sites 4.1. Effect of Pt content A series of Pt/H/323 catalysts with different Pt contents (from 0.1 to 3 wt%) have been prepared by the ion-exchange technique. Results of n-heptane transformation over these Pt/H/3 catalysts at 230 are shown in Fig. 8. An increase in Pt content caused an increase in the selectivity to isomers. The conversion of n-heptane and the fraction of multi-branched isomers in C7-isomers were almost independent of Pt content. The effect of Pt content in enhancing the selectivity to isomers is attributed to its role of hydrogenating the intermediate olefins (see Scheme 1). The absence of methane and ethane reveals that hydrogenolysis does not contribute to the cracking for Pt loadings lower than 2.5 wt%. In addition, the high yield of isomers, 61.5%, was obtained at 220 over 3 wt% Pt/H/323 catalyst. ZB. Wang et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 119-132 129 80 100 60 20 0 " L." Effect of Si/Al n-Heptane transformation over Pt/H/3 catalysts with different Si/A1 ratios (18, 21 and 30) at 230 is illustrated in Fig. 9. The conversion was varied, at the constant reaction temperature, by changing W/E The conversion of n-heptane decreased with increasing the Si/A1 ratio, under the same reaction conditions. The selectivity to isomers at the same conversion was in the order: Pt/H/330>Pt/H/321>Pt/H/318. In zeolites with higher Si/A1 ratios, where the acid density is lower, each intermediate olefin formed at Pt dehydrogenating site comes into contact with very few acid sites between two Pt sites (see Scheme 1, path A), which could favorably lead to the formation of isomerized products. In zeolites with lower Si/A1 ratios, each intermediate olefin comes into contact with more acid sites between two Pt sites (path B), which could lead to the formation of cracking products. The performance of Pt/H/321 at 220 is also shown in Fig. 9. The selectivity of Pt/H/321 at the same conversion was higher at 220 than that at 230, and the former was even higher than the selectivity of Pt/H/330. These results indicate that the lower the reaction temperature, the higher the selectivity to isomers. This suggests that the high selectivity to isomers can be obtained by using H/3 zeolites with lower Si/AI ratios at low reaction temperatures, keeping the conversion levels sufficiently high. 130 Z.B. As already described, although the selectivity to isomers over Pt/H~21 is lower than that over Pt/HY7 (see Table 1 ), the former can be increased by decreasing the number of acid sites of Hi3 or by lowering the reaction temperature. 5. Conclusions The activity of Pt/H/7 catalyst is higher than that of Pt/HY catalyst, because of the stronger acidity of the former. Therefore, n-heptane isomerization can be carried out over Pt/H/7 catalyst at a lower reaction temperature. Cracking products are mainly propane and isobutane, 99%, which mainly come from 2-MHex and 2,4-DMP. Pt/H/3 catalyst shows a good stability for n-heptane isomerization under the following reaction conditions: reaction temperature, 220; W/F, 3.2 g h tool- i. molar ratio of H2 to n-heptane, 7.5. The higher the Pt content, the higher the selectivity to isomers. The lower the amount of acid sites of zeolite/3, the higher the selectivity to isomers at the same conversion. The influence of key parameters in the isomerization of n-heptane over Pt-loaded Hβ catalysts was studied at temperatures lower than 250°C under atmospheric pressure. The highest yield of isomerized products was obtained at 210°C. The conversion of n-heptane increased with contact time (W/F), while the selectivity to isomers decreased. The higher the hydrogen partial pressure, the higher the selectivity to isomers. It was found thatPt/Hβ catalyst showed a good stability for 78 h at the reaction temperature of 220°C. The effect of metallic sites and acid sites (Si/Al ratios) on the catalytic property was studied. The higher the content of Pt, the higher the selectivity to isomers, and the lower the acidity of zeolite β, the higher the selectivity to isomers at the same conversion.
